messages.content:
I'll help you identify the seven traits that God loves according to the Quran, along with their opposites and the relevant verses.

Based on my research, here are the seven characteristics that God loves as mentioned in the Quran:

1. **Al-Muhsineen (Those who do good)**
   - Verse: "And do good; indeed, Allah loves the doers of good." (Quran 2:195)
   - Opposite: Wrongdoers

2. **Al-Muttaqeen (The righteous/God-conscious)**
   - Verse: "Indeed, Allah loves the righteous." (Quran 3:76)
   - Opposite: The unrighteous/heedless

3. **Al-Mutawakkileen (Those who trust in Allah)**
   - Verse: "Indeed, Allah loves those who rely [upon Him]." (Quran 3:159)
   - Opposite: Those who place trust elsewhere

4. **Al-Mutatahhireen (Those who purify themselves)**
   - Verse: "Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves." (Quran 2:222)
   - Opposite: Those who remain impure

5. **Al-Tawwabeen (Those who constantly repent)**
   - Verse: "Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves." (Quran 2:222)
   - Opposite: Those who persist in sin

6. **Al-Muqsiteen (Those who act justly)**
   - Verse: "Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly." (Quran 5:42)
   - Opposite: The unjust

7. **Al-Sabireen (The patient ones)**
   - Verse: "And Allah loves the steadfast." (Quran 3:146)
   - Opposite: The impatient

These traits form a framework for moral and spiritual development in Islamic teachings, much like a garden where each quality represents a different type of plant that needs cultivation and care to thrive in the spiritual landscape.

Is there any particular trait from this list you'd like to explore further?

input.title: Ramadan Reflection: The Seven Traits Allah Loves
input.content:
بِسْمِ اللهِ الرَّحْمٰنِ الرَّحِيمِ

The Seven Characteristics Allah Loves

A Ramadan Journey of Spiritual Growth

The blessed month of Ramadan offers us a unique opportunity to cultivate the qualities that are most beloved to Allah. As we fast from food and drink, we also strive to nourish our souls by embodying the characteristics that draw us closer to our Creator.

This Ramadan guide explores seven traits that Allah loves, as mentioned in the Quran, along with practical ways to develop them during this holy month. Each characteristic serves as a spiritual milestone on our journey of self-improvement.

Ramadan: A Month of Transformation

Ramadan is not merely about abstaining from food and drink—it's about transforming our character to align with divine guidance. The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ said: "Whoever does not give up false speech and acting upon it, Allah has no need of his leaving his food and drink." (Bukhari)

Let us use these blessed days and nights to cultivate the traits that Allah loves and eliminate those He dislikes.

Humility (التواضع)

1
وَعِبَادُ الرَّحْمَٰنِ الَّذِينَ يَمْشُونَ عَلَى الْأَرْضِ هَوْنًا وَإِذَا خَاطَبَهُمُ الْجَاهِلُونَ قَالُوا سَلَامًا
"And the servants of the Most Merciful are those who walk upon the earth in humility, and when the ignorant address them, they say words of peace."
Quran 25:63

Humility

Recognizing one's proper place before Allah and treating others with respect regardless of their status.

Pride

Quran 31:18 - "And do not turn your cheek [in contempt] toward people and do not walk through the earth exultantly. Indeed, Allah does not like everyone self-deluded and boastful."

Ramadan Application:

During Ramadan, when we experience hunger and thirst, we naturally remember our dependence on Allah's provisions. This state reminds us of our vulnerability and need for Allah, fostering genuine humility.

When breaking fast with others, practice serving them first. Join community iftars where people from all walks of life gather, reminding us of our equality before Allah.

Practical Tips for Cultivating Humility:

  • Perform extra acts of service for others during Ramadan without seeking recognition
  • When praying Taraweeh, choose a spot in the back rows occasionally
  • Listen more than you speak during iftar gatherings
  • Seek knowledge about the Prophet's ﷺ examples of humility
  • Make dua asking Allah to purify your heart from pride

Forgiveness (العفو)

2
الَّذِينَ يُنفِقُونَ فِي السَّرَّاءِ وَالضَّرَّاءِ وَالْكَاظِمِينَ الْغَيْظَ وَالْعَافِينَ عَنِ النَّاسِ ۗ وَاللَّهُ يُحِبُّ الْمُحْسِنِينَ
"Who spend [in the cause of Allah] during ease and hardship and who restrain anger and who pardon the people - and Allah loves the doers of good."
Quran 3:134

Forgiveness

Pardoning others' faults and letting go of resentment, even when justified in anger.

Retaliation

Quran 42:40 - "And the retribution for an evil act is an evil one like it, but whoever pardons and makes reconciliation - his reward is [due] from Allah."

Ramadan Application:

Ramadan is a month of mercy and forgiveness from Allah. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever does not forgive others will not be forgiven by Allah." This month presents a perfect opportunity to heal broken relationships.

Consider that Laylatul Qadr (the Night of Power) is a night when Allah forgives sins. How can we seek Allah's forgiveness while holding grudges against others?

Practical Tips for Developing Forgiveness:

  • Dedicate the first 10 days of Ramadan to identifying relationships that need healing
  • During the middle 10 days, reach out to those you've harbored resentment toward
  • In the last 10 days, when seeking Allah's forgiveness most intensely, complete the act of reconciliation
  • Make a specific dua for those who have wronged you during your prayers
  • When feeling anger rising during fasting, recall the hadith that fasting is a shield

Truthfulness (الصدق)

3
يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا اتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَكُونُوا مَعَ الصَّادِقِينَ
"O you who have believed, fear Allah and be with those who are true."
Quran 9:119

Truthfulness

Being honest in speech, intention, and action, maintaining integrity in all circumstances.

Deception

Quran 4:145 - "Indeed, the hypocrites will be in the lowest depths of the Fire - and never will you find for them a helper."

Ramadan Application:

Fasting itself is an exercise in truthfulness—only Allah knows if you've truly fasted. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Fasting is not [abstaining] from eating and drinking only, but also from vain speech and foul language."

During Ramadan, we have the opportunity to align our inner reality with our outer actions, embodying truthfulness in its fullest sense.

Practical Tips for Cultivating Truthfulness:

  • Take a personal inventory each night about moments of complete honesty versus moments of exaggeration or deception
  • Practice being precise in describing events or sharing stories at iftar gatherings
  • Make fulfilling promises a priority, especially regarding Ramadan commitments
  • Study the stories of Abu Bakr as-Siddiq, known as "The Truthful"
  • Before speaking, pause and ask yourself if what you're about to say is completely true

Compassion (الرحمة)

4
ثُمَّ كَانَ مِنَ الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وَتَوَاصَوْا بِالصَّبْرِ وَتَوَاصَوْا بِالْمَرْحَمَةِ
"Then being among those who believed and advised one another to patience and advised one another to compassion."
Quran 90:17

Compassion

Feeling empathy for others' suffering and taking action to alleviate it.

Harshness

Quran 3:159 - "So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them. And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have disbanded from about you."

Ramadan Application:

Ramadan heightens our awareness of those who experience hunger regularly. The Prophet ﷺ was most generous during Ramadan, reminding us that this month is a time to increase our compassion through action.

When experiencing hunger during fasting, use that feeling to connect with the suffering of others, and let it motivate greater charitable acts.

Practical Tips for Developing Compassion:

  • Commit to a daily sadaqah (charity) during Ramadan, even if small
  • Volunteer at community iftars for the needy
  • Sponsor an orphan's needs for Ramadan and Eid
  • Practice active listening when others share their struggles during Ramadan gatherings
  • Make specific duas for those suffering around the world during your night prayers

Patience (الصبر)

5
وَاللَّهُ يُحِبُّ الصَّابِرِينَ
"And Allah loves the steadfast."
Quran 3:146

Patience

Remaining steadfast during hardship, persevering without complaint or despair.

Impatience

Quran 70:19-20 - "Indeed, mankind was created anxious: When evil touches him, impatient."

Ramadan Application:

Fasting is the ultimate exercise in patience. It teaches us to delay gratification and control our immediate desires. The Prophet ﷺ described fasting as half of patience.

Each day of Ramadan provides an opportunity to strengthen your patience muscle—through hunger, thirst, controlling anger, and persisting in worship despite fatigue.

Practical Tips for Building Patience:

  • When feeling hungry or thirsty, remind yourself that this temporary discomfort is building your capacity for patience
  • Set a goal to complete a lengthy act of worship (like reading the entire Quran) in small, consistent segments
  • Practice extended dhikr (remembrance) during times when you would normally reach for your phone
  • When facing conflict while fasting, take three deep breaths before responding
  • Study the story of Prophet Ayyub (Job) during Ramadan to draw inspiration from his patience

Gratitude (الشكر)

6
إِن تَشْكُرُوا يَرْضَهُ لَكُمْ
"If you are grateful, He is pleased with you."
Quran 39:7

Gratitude

Recognizing and expressing thanks for Allah's countless blessings, both in heart and action.

Complaint

Quran 14:34 - "And He gave you from all you asked of Him. And if you should count the favor of Allah, you could not enumerate them. Indeed, mankind is [generally] most unjust and ungrateful."

Ramadan Application:

Ramadan helps us appreciate blessings we normally take for granted—like a simple glass of water or a warm meal. The temporary deprivation awakens genuine gratitude.

Iftar time becomes a powerful moment to practice gratitude. The Prophet ﷺ would say upon breaking his fast: "The thirst has gone, the veins are moistened, and the reward is confirmed, if Allah wills."

Practical Tips for Developing Gratitude:

  • Keep a Ramadan gratitude journal, writing three new blessings each day
  • Before iftar, spend 5 minutes reflecting on blessings beyond food and drink
  • Express gratitude to those who prepare your iftar meals
  • Say "Alhamdulillah" (praise be to Allah) at least 100 times daily
  • Donate to provide iftar for those in need as an expression of gratitude for your provisions

Contentment (القناعة)

7
وَلَوْ أَنَّهُمْ رَضُوا مَا آتَاهُمُ اللَّهُ وَرَسُولُهُ وَقَالُوا حَسْبُنَا اللَّهُ سَيُؤْتِينَا اللَّهُ مِن فَضْلِهِ وَرَسُولُهُ إِنَّا إِلَى اللَّهِ رَاغِبُونَ
"If only they had been satisfied with what Allah and His Messenger gave them and said, 'Sufficient for us is Allah; Allah will give us of His bounty, and [so will] His Messenger; indeed, we are desirous toward Allah.'"
Quran 9:59

Contentment

Being satisfied with what Allah has decreed, finding peace regardless of circumstances.

Covetousness

Quran 4:32 - "And do not wish for that by which Allah has made some of you exceed others."

Ramadan Application:

During Ramadan, many people simplify their lives, focusing on worship rather than consumption. This shift helps us discover that contentment comes from spiritual richness, not material abundance.

The nights of Ramadan remind us that our ultimate satisfaction lies in our connection with Allah, not in worldly possessions or achievements.

Practical Tips for Cultivating Contentment:

  • Simplify your iftar meals occasionally, experiencing the joy of moderation
  • Avoid shopping during Ramadan except for necessities
  • Reduce social media usage which often triggers comparison and discontent
  • Practice the dua: "O Allah, make me content with what You have provided me"
  • Spend time with those who have less than you materially but display contentment

Ramadan 30-Day Challenge: Cultivating the Beloved Traits

Consider focusing on developing one trait each week of Ramadan, with overlapping days to strengthen your practice:

1-5
Humility
5-10
Forgiveness
10-15
Truthfulness
15-20
Compassion
20-25
Patience
25-28
Gratitude
28-30
Contentment

Special Dua for Developing Beloved Characteristics

اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي أَسْأَلُكَ حُبَّكَ وَحُبَّ مَنْ يُحِبُّكَ وَحُبَّ عَمَلٍ يُقَرِّبُنِي إِلَى حُبِّكَ
"O Allah, I ask You for Your love, the love of those who love You, and love for the actions that bring me closer to Your love."

This beautiful dua from the Prophet Muhammad

Continuing Your Journey Beyond Ramadan

While we focus intensely on these traits during Ramadan, our goal should be to carry them forward throughout the year. The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ said, "The most beloved of deeds to Allah are those that are consistent, even if they are small."

As we continue through the remaining days of Ramadan, let each trait become a lens through which we view our interactions with others and with Allah. The transformative power of fasting lies not only in abstaining from food and drink but in nurturing these characteristics that Allah loves.

Self-Assessment Questions

  • Which of these seven traits comes most naturally to you?
  • Which trait do you find most challenging to develop?
  • How has your understanding of these traits deepened since Ramadan began?
  • What practical step can you take today to strengthen the trait you're currently focusing on?
  • How can you design your post-Ramadan routine to maintain growth in these areas?

May Allah accept our fasting, prayers, and efforts to embody the characteristics He loves. May He make us among those who grow closer to Him with each passing day of Ramadan and beyond.

"The believers with the most complete faith are those with the best character." - Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
